intro: Pfaffia gnaphalioides f. subferruginea, commonly known as the iron-hued false heather, is a rare and striking plant characterized by its distinctive rust-colored foliage. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is native to specific regions of South America, particularly Brazil. The plant features small, clustered flowers that bloom in shades of yellow and orange, adding to its ornamental appeal. Its leaves are typically lance-shaped and covered in a fine, powdery coating that gives them their unique coloration. Due to its limited distribution and ornamental value, it is often cultivated in specialized gardens and botanical collections.
